headline: Quick and Easy Refried Beans
description: These refried beans are made with pinto beans, garlic, spices, and lime in just 20 minutes. A perfect recipe for Taco Tuesdays or any weeknight!
name: Quick and Easy Refried Beans

recipeInstructions.text: Heat canola oil in a heavy skillet over medium heat.
Cook garlic cloves in hot oil, turning once, until brown on both sides, 4 to 5 minutes. Smash garlic cloves in the skillet with a fork.
Stir pinto beans, cumin, chili powder, and salt into mashed garlic and cook until beans are thoroughly heated, about 5 minutes. Stir occasionally.
Smash bean mixture with a potato masher to desired texture. Squeeze lime juice over smashed beans and stir until combined.

review.reviewBody: Fast easy and delicious. I used bacon grease instead of the oil. Followed the rest of the recipe exactly. I drained about 1/2 of the liquid from the beans and did not add any salt. Simmered for about 15 minutes or so, after mashing to allow the liquid to evaporate to allow the seasoning to fully incorporate. Just finished eating these refried beans. They were delicious and my picky family loved them too. Thank you.
All-Recipes always hits the nail on the head, gotta say, and this was no exception! Absolutely simple and D-liscious!
These re-fried beans were so delicious! I ate mine with a nice salad and veggie chips. Seasonings are always a surprise. They make more of a difference than expected.
Awesome, thank you!! I never knew how easy it was to make these. I halved the recipe and used minced garlic instead of cloves, and added cayenne. Turned out perfect. I drained 90% of bean juice.

We usually go for the canned stuff but forgot to get it last time. I had a can of pinto beans and everything already on this recipe, so figured, why not? I didn't change the recipe at all and these came out perfect. I kept some of the juice from the pinto beans to make sure it didn't come out as paste. Everyone loved it and it's easier to make than cleaning a can of pre-made to heat it up. I'm hoping the half lime is about 1/8 cup because that amount seems to work prefect for us.
It was missing something, but I'm not sure what. Only made 1/2 batch and used leftover pinto beans instead of canned. Definitely easy! I will make again and play around with my spices.

I rarely write reviews… I have to say this recipe is hands down the best I’ve come across! This is better than any pre-made canned refried beans. I followed recipe to the T. Well, I used olive oil, & one can of organic black beans… with the juice, per other reviewers not knowing because the recipe doesn’t disclose. I just made sure to let cook on low-medium and simmer to reduce the liquid to the right consistency. To make a double batch, I will use 4 cloves of garlic. Thank you!!!!!!
Perfect! So fast and easy! Very authentic
Quick & easy. So much better than canned refried beans. I added a little bit of onion and just a touch of cayenne pepper, very tasty. A definite keeper to make again.
A little more garlic and boom delicious

decent recipe although I added a garlic black pepper salt mix to help kick up the flavor. I added the liquid with the beans and it was way too runny, so I strained another can of pinto beans and added them in mixing it with a food processor. Still very runny so I’m now trying to cook down some of the liquid on low for a little bit. Next time I try this recipe I will do it without the liquid and then add some back in as needed.

I used the recipe as the base. I made half the recipe so did this: 1 can pinto beans, drained and rinsed 1 tblsp. avocado oil 1 very large clove garlic, peeled and diced 1/4 tsp. cumin 1/4 tsp. Mexican Oregano 1/4 tsp. Fajita seasoning water, as needed, for thinning Saute the garlic for about a minute, add the spices and stir until fragrant (1-2 minutes) Add beans and heat through then mash until consistency you desire. If needed add water 1 Tablespoon at a time until desired consistency. It was very flavorful and a great topping to my nachos.
I added 2 teaspoons of butter and minced red onions near the end of the cooking, and these are freaking awesome!!!
Amazing dish. Perfect with chilli con carne and a semi-pickled cabbage dish.
Easy to make. I made it boiling my own pinto beans. My husband and I liked it very much

These beans turned out way dry, with too little flavor. If I did them again, I would slowly add broth throughout cooking to keep them moist. They also were really missing that umami flavor of good refried beans. I'd chalk that up to the lack of lard and bacon grease. I added a little butter to add more of a fatty flavor and some water at the very end, and it made them a little better. Wouldn't make this recipe again.

made it for supper to go with leftover ham & brown rice & salad. Tasty but spicier than I expected. I did sub a teaspoon of chipotle molido for the chili powder. I drained the beans and reserved the liquid, adding most of it back at the end when I could see the final texture. Next time I won't bother draining.
Great recipe! I did not drain the beans so they ended up being a great consistency. I did add cheese to them but they were much better than precious recipes I have tried.
This was delicious. I had to substitute lemon juice I wink definitely make again - many times!!
The whole family love them, super easy and quick...great flavor!
This was so easy and yummy!
This is an amazing recipe! The best refried beans EVER! So easy and fast and tastes just as good as the ones made from dried beans. It’s now my very favorite refried bean recipe!

Made it as written with beans from my freezer instead of canned. I cook a batch of beans and freeze several bags about once every 6 weeks. After tasting, we decided to add more spices, hot sauce etc, but this is a personal choice. The recipe as written is good and not too spicy for those who prefer a milder taste.
Need to include liquid from cans. Add more cumin, chili powder, and salt, almost double.
Fast and very easy. But watery but flavor on point.

I thought is was excellent! I wasn't sure if I was supposed to drain the beans or not, so I read through the comments and decided not to drain the beans. Since I was making burritos, I probably should have drained one of the cans. I just cooked it longer. I used a bit more cumin and chili powder. Very tasty! Thanks!
For a quick side in a hurry, these were delish!
I add chopped onion and sautéed with the garlic. It was delicious! and very easy to make!

Made the pinto beans in the crockpot and reserved some liquid. When it says salt to taste- salt generously if you use low-sodium canned beans or don't add salt while cooking. Delicious. :) I've made this recipe multiple times and sometimes I add jalapeño or extra lime too.

It was incredibly easy to make. It was a little bit soupy and the potato masher did not mash the beans as well as I wanted. Next time. I'll put them in the food processor or the mixer to achieve the desired consistency.

good recipe, dash of cayenne for the extra kick. strain your liquid out but keep it and use it to thin out the beans as you turn them into a paste till you get the texture you desire. makes good bean dip also.
I used the beans with liquid. Simmered for about 20 minutes, then mashed. These were so much better than canned refried beans.

This is a great semi-homemade recipe. I never remember whether to drain the beans or pour the whole can into the skillet. I just made it again without draining and it takes a long time for the liquid to burn off. If possible, I would drain half the liquid.
Absolutely delicious! Made it exact to recipe. My husband tried a little bite and was hooked

Just made this! So good! Like many other reviewers, I’ll never buy canned refried beans again. And these are good enough, I may never make them from scratch again. Made them pretty much just like the recipe. Used the oil, but stirred in a pat of butter when they were almost to the right texture. I paid $8.00 for a jar of whole cumin seeds last week, so I’m trying to put them in everything. Toasted them for about 5 minutes in a skillet, then ground them with a mortar and pestle. They had texture that added a little interest. Wasn’t sure about the half of lime, but holy smokes, that was the perfect finishing touch! Thank you for a new favorite!.

This recipe was great! I used black beans, since that's what I had and didn't drain them (as other reviewers recommended). My oil must have been too hot, since my garlic burnt pretty bad. I tossed it. I used an immersion blender since I don't have a masher. It was great. Don't wait until it's the perfect consistency, since it will solidify somewhat. Leave it a little liquidy and it will firm up as it starts to cool.
Very bland as is. I had to doctor it up but still wasn't the best. I think I'll stick with premade.

I drained and rinsed the beans, I don't care for the starchy liquid. After cooking and mashing I added water, a teaspoon at a time until I reached the desired consistency. Will increase the cumin next time. Very good!
This recipe was pretty good. I had issues with the different textures as well as my undercooking the tortilla. Crispy is way better.
These turned out really well, I found this recipe because I was in a pinch, I had no canned refried beans but I had pinto beans. Worked great with with nachos!

I really like this recipe. There's plenty of leeway to play with flavors.
The only modification I regularly make is to cook dried pintos in my pressure cooker instead of using canned beans.
I took the advice of some of the others and added rendered bacon fat. I also added a dash of garlic salt for additional flavor. #Delicious!

I love how quick and easy this recipe is. Great to throw together last minute or when you don't feel like cooking.
I added some onion but pretty much stuck with the recipe. Good stuff. Didn't have a lot of veggies on hand but this made a great little burrito with shredded cheese and mango salsa wrapped in a tortilla.
will definitely make this again.
We really liked this recipe. I used white beans and it was fine. I liked how quick and easy the recipe is.
loved it
So simple to make. I will never buy canned refried beans again
This recipe is way better than canned and just as easy. I served this with Queso Fresco and my family loved it!

Quick and simple to follow. 
I recommend using the blender instead of a potato masher.
Great easy recipe especially when you under pressure from the kids to put something together
Yum! Easy. I used this to make a tamale pie.

didn't have refried on hand for my taco casserole so I threw these together. made as directed except I rinsed beans before frying with garlic oil and substituted the bean juice with 1/2 cup of chicken stock while mashing. I also only added 1/2 teaspoon of cumin since other reviewers said it was a little too strong. also omitted lime juice only because I'm using in a casserole. but let me just say that these came out AWESOME. definitely worth the 5 stars.
Good quick recipe. I used from pinto beans that I had pre-cooked from dry instead of canned.

First time making a dish like this, only because we wanted a side to go with our tacos. Never really liked eating this before when eaten at a restaurant. However, this recipe changed that, very tasty the only thing I amended was adding lime. I didn't have any lime so instead I substituted with a splash of apple cider vinegar. DELICIOUS!
i love this recipe! its simple and the lime addition is perfect. I didn't have pinto beans but i did have navy beans and it tastes just as good.

This is a good recipe. I used four garlic cloves and one half of the cumin. Next time I will add a little paprika, as one reviewer did. I added a couple of tablespoons of milk to handle the dryness of the lightly drained beans. Finally, I added a handful of grated Mexican (or cheddar) cheese. My house loves them. We eat them with many of out meals
Everything went great. No problems. Directions were easy for this newby! Thank you very much.

Great especially if you are in a pinch need refried beans but don’t have the time and grocery stores are sold out! Super easy too!1 I would add some chicken bullion/chicken stock next time. I did add both chili powder and cumin, dried minced onion, a little taco seasoning and parsley flakes. Some of it went to taco salad and some for chips and dipping. The dipping ones I added shredded cheese. Yummmy!! Definitely worth making again. Reminded me if restaurant style refried

Quick and Easy. I cooked my hamburger meat first, and then used the pan drippings to saute the garlic and then added everything on top. I even mashed the beans in the cast iron skillet so it saved me another dish. The seasoning wasn't over kill either. Thank you for posting this recipe.
I used kidney beans. I used minced garlic and didn't fry it. I cut the recipe in half. It worked perfectly! I served it over white rice. It was delicous!

Great Recipe! I'm so glad I found this recipe! I Invited guest over for enchiladas and needed this as a side dish at the last minute. I used 2 cans of re fried beans, added the spice ingredients then heated in the microwave. 
My wife loved them and wants me to make re fried beans this way from now on!!! YUMMY!
I tweak this to my taste, double the seasoning and add a little cream with more lime juice!
Very good. I fried up some bacon first and used the fat instead of canola oil. Also added chicken broth to the beans because I rinsed and drained them before adding to the pot.

I used bacon grease as others suggested. I left the broth in the pinto beans and let them cook down, smashing them with the back of my wooden spoon. I forgot to add the lime juice but we loved them anyway! I will make again whenever I want refried beans.
They were much too watery and the flavor was odd.
Made homemade pinto beans and used fresh garlic to make these creamy, perfectly spiced refried beans. So good, I will never buy another can again.
They were very tasty, but I added some water to mine since the mixture was too dry.
First time making beans, not a bad recipe but I felt like the refried beans turned out kinda dry. It was easy enough to make though.

This turned out delicious. I was looking for new flavor combinations for my weekly bean wraps and this was a perfect start. I added onions, increased the cumin and lime juice, and added a dash of cinnamon. I dis not drain my beans to allow more liquid and added and some farro. Served the beans on flour street taco wraps with avocado slices, black olives, and romaine lettuce. They were delicious.
Quick and easy and taste great!

It was good but, the incorporation of seasoning and lime just reminded me how American white wash dishes that are typically simple. Over all I enjoyed it but I think I’m just gonna stick to what I know

Really good base, I omitted the lime juice, used black beans (all I had) and I added finely diced onion and sautéed on low until tender then adding the garlic and half of a diced jalapeno. For extra flavor, I added about a teaspoon each of oregano and chipotle pepper. I also reserved the can liquid and added only what was needed because I prefer to add my own salt to taste, plus I threw in a little bit of chicken broth.
I'll always make this a day in advance; allows time for great flavor to come out.
This is a good quick recipe, especially if you use crushed garlic from a jar like me :) and the only tweak to the recipe - I would suggest is to add a line, saying "season to taste"

These beans were delicious! I did use butter instead of oil (did not have canola on hand). I also used 1 can of pinto and 1 can of black beans, and kept most of the liquid. I partially mashed them with a potato masher. I will make these again; thank you!

I sauted some fine diced onion with the garlic and bloomed the spices in that. I did cook my canned beans in chicken stock to soften them a little. Then I added them to the saute and added some liquid from prior cooking of the beans and mashed. I did use bacon grease instead. I think they came out very good. Handy recipe to have on had.

I didn’t have pinto beans, so I used a can of kidney beans and a can of black beans. Since these are not necessarily traditional beans to use for this, I did add a bit of extra flavor by including a packet of onion soup mix and let it simmer for a bit before I added the other spices to it. But man, this was delicious and so easy! This will definitely be added to our rotation. Thank you so much!
Easy and tasty on street tacos with a little salsa!

I made these beans and they were great! I made half the recipe and used 1 teaspoon minced garlic, sautéing lightly, for like 1 minute. I didn’t drain the beans, I just dumped them by themselves with 1/2 teaspoon each of salt, cumin and chili powder. They are very flavorful and perfect for my family members because it is not spicy. 5 minutes was enough to meld all flavors. They mashed beautifully and thickened in their own. I won’t be buying refried beans anymore.
I used my own cooked pinto beans and used lard for flavor other than that I used your recipe...came out delicious! Thanks:)

This was a very easy recipe and with a few tweaks got some superb flavor out of it. Per others suggestions I used bacon grease for the oil and sweated a halt cup diced onions with the garlic. I also doubled the cumin and chili powder. The texture was good, but I think next time I'll only leave liquid in one can of beans instead of both.

After trying 30 minute pinto beans in our new Quick Cooker, we decided to make refried beans from them. No cooking for us! We drained the beans, added the seasoning, doubling the cumin and lime juice, with the addition of Southwestern Seasoning that I had on hand. Delicious! I'm sorry for the changes, as I feel that its really not the same recipe, but this became a great basis for something with a little more flavor that we prefer.

I've made these she the only thing I add to them is a bit of butter of bacon grease, pickling juice from the can of jalapenos that's always in the fridge and add cheese once heated. perfection! the house from the jalapenos gives it a needed kick.
used black eyed peas with jalapeno

This recipe does what it says on the tin: quick and easy. As written, the result was more than acceptable.

Keep in mind liquid from the can when figuring the final consistency. You may need to drain one or both cans, or let the excess liquid cook off if you want something thicker.
Tasted amazing. Better than most of the restaurants I have been to. Will never buy canned refried beans again.

Was very good, however my family thought it lacked in flavor. Texture was great, only drained some of the juice from one can as I was afraid beans would be too runny. Will make again, but maybe next time add more of the seasonings.

I’ve made this recipe lots of times. The spices are perfect. I use water instead of oil to make them fat free. I like it better with real cloves of garlic, but I’ve used 1 tsp of granulated garlic in a pinch with good results. I add 1 tsp onion powder and viola perfection. I use beans I cook from dried, but I’m sure it would be good with canned too. 

To make this recipe even quicker, I don’t smash anything. The spices are right. The only difference is the presentation.

Very good! Although I did change things a bit! Didn't have pinto beans, used great northern. Drained some of the liquid off, but not all! Only other thing I did was eliminate the salt, added 1/2 chopped onion, add 1/2 tsp. cayenne pepper because we really like more heat! Great recipe though...so much better than the gross ones in the stores!!
Really good. I did not have a potato masher so I did the best I could with a fork. Will buy a masher for next time.

I recently moved to Japan and I've been trying my damnedest to try to recreate my favorite foods with ingredients I can find here (and I. in a pretty rural area to boot). So far it's been pretty hot or miss so I was sceptical this would come out at all like what I'm used to, especially since I haven't been able to source any pinto beans around me. I tried this recipe on a whim with some borlotti beans that I found at a foreign goods store and I must say, I'm impressed with how it came out.
Yes added onion parsley!
I did add about 1/4C fat free chicken stock because I thought i was a little too thick for the recipe I needed it for. But it was phenomenal! I may never buy refried beans again!
Good texture and great taste. Quick and easy to make.

The instructions didn’t say to drain or not and I drained this before reading comments, so my version includes draining the beans, adding onion powder and smoked paprika. I measured the garlic and lime juice with my heart. These were delicious!
I put them in the blender and it came out more smooth. very delicious .
This was in fact really quick and easy! I didn't drain the beans, and just let it cook a little longer than the recipe recommended until it got to a nice texture.
Wow, this recipe really is quick and easy! Delicious too! I followed the recipe exactly and loved...thanks!

Easy and delicious. I made the recipe exactly as written except I did not rinse the beans and I used some of the liquid in the canned beans to get the consistency I wanted. I will not buy canned refried beans again.

I only had red and white kidney beans. I also had a few strips of bacon that I added, primarily just to use it up. And at the last minute I added about a tsp of red chili flakes. I love that little bit of lime that hints around on the taste-buds. I might just eat it all before it makes it to the dip I was planning on making. Will make this over and over again.
